title: How player behavior penalties affect Hextech Crafting
body:
Hey everyone, 

Now that Hextech Crafting is live in most parts of the world, let’s take a breather and talk about how our philosophy around rewarding sportsmanship influences the overall system. Outstanding performances, teamwork, and sportsmanship are what earns you chests and keys. Let’s clarify the sportsmanship part. 

We want to focus on creating rewards and incentives for consistently sportsmanlike players. That’s why previously penalized players need to demonstrate commitment to positive play over time, even after wrapping up a chat restriction or ban. It’s also why we’ve decided against sharing the exact requirements for restoring access to earned loot. Doing so would encourage good sportsmanship for a defined period, and not much longer. 

To add some clarity, more severe infractions incur longer ineligibility periods. If you’re currently ineligible for earned content, this is on you. Since Hextech launched, we’ve seen a meaningful number of players earn access to the system’s rewards. Stay focused on solid comms, teamwork, and sportsmanship in your games and you’ll be earning chests, keys, and loot sooner rather than later. 

This approach reflects how we’ll build reward systems going forward, awarding the majority sweet loot, and temporarily excluding the minority while they prove they can stick to the community’s standards. There’s a ton of space to explore in recognizing and rewarding sportsmanship and we’re psyched about the possibilities for the future of League.

Not even by your statement is that true.
A system being automated does not mean reports lead directly to punishment.
In an automated system, the reports would still lead to a review.
Its just that the _**review**_ is done by the automated system.

Which means there are a set of rules that system follows, and as such a set of rules you can follow to avoid punishment.

So no, reports do _**not**_ lead directly to punishment.

Yes. It does. You can say absolutely nothing, and still be reported and punished for it.  Because the whole system works on a stance that because you are reported, you must have done something wrong to be reported in the first place.

Actually, Erdrik is correct here.

A report flags a game for review. They do not establish guilt. The game is then reviewed for harassment, feeding, etc. This is why 'troll reporting' or 'gang reporting' do not work. False or inaccurate reports are thrown out.

> You can say absolutely nothing, and still be reported and punished for it. 

You cannot ever be punished for saying nothing .. unless of course it's for something gameplay related like feeding, afking or cheating. But, you can never be punished for offensive language, hate speech or verbal abuse if you said nothing.

As I said in another post in this thread, I could give a crap about the hextech rewards in this. I have too many skins already, and if you feel that taking it away is an effective punishment to correct behavior, than I'm willing to put up with it for a few months, I suppose. My problem is the constant needling of the "rewards" system. I can't play a game that is going to remind me of one bad day I had a couple of weeks ago for an indefinite amount of time. In short, I'm not mad about not getting free stuff. Constantly being hounded by the system that distributes those rewards, however, caused me to uninstall the game.

I don't want to stop playing League, as it's my favorite game, and there's a lot of really cool stuff coming down the pipe in it. Unfortunately, if I can't get more than a "it'll happen at some point if you just don't act toxic", I can't really see myself putting up with every game ending by telling me "Your performance doesn't matter because you were toxic one time. LOL suck it pleb." It's really, REALLY disheartening, frustrating, and unnecessarily punitive.

I'd love to reinstall the game and use the lack of hextech as an excuse to just buy more skins with cash, but as long as the game itself is being more toxic than I ever was, I have 0 reason to do so.
The 3 months thing is being misquoted. This belongs to the tier punishment system (10 chat, 25 chat, 14 day ban, permaban).

And it has been stated that 3 months without a penalty will drop your next penalty one tier in that system.

So for 2 months (if he receives another penalty in that time), it would be a permanent ban. 3 months after that (with no penalties), it would again be a 14 day ban, followed by 3 months of 25 chat restriction, then it would finally drop to a 10 (being "clean" at that point), for a total of 8 months.

He is assuming that you need to be at that "clean" point to receive Hextech material. (Not going to say whether the assumption is correct.)

It's been a couple months of no restrictions (got them before hextech even came out), but I'm not about to say "gl hf" every game or "gj" for every single thing or "omg sorry" for every single mistake just to receive rewards. I'll do what I think is fair- and that is to stop retaliating to actual trolls. But I will not go out of my way to be this disingenuous nice guy.

You have to realize that the community standards are very very low on the average game. It's harder to tolerate people than it is to win the game itself. You're saying we have to not only play nice, but act nice by communicating with encouragement and whatnot? Why? That isn't reformation, that's "pseudo change".

Define sportsmanlike. Because for me, it's hard enough to simply keep my fingers off the keyboard when I see someone go off the rails on me or my friends or even random teammates. Me keeping quiet and playing the game as normal, is me being sportsmanlike. I compare it to as much of an IRL scenario as I can. IRL- I would've walked away from the game long ago, and everyone else too. But we can't do that. What I wouldn't do, is talk nice to the person and encourage positive behavior, because that person isn't worth talking to.

You keep talking about displaying sportsmanship as if this miraculous set of words will change a person from the inside out.
I could be that fake nice person, and fool the system into thinking I was a "reformed" player. Am I now reformed? No. I am no different than I was yesterday.

Once you have served your time, you've served your time. The need for a double whammy (and the constant you are ineligible for loot because of previous restrictions) just confuses me. Maybe not for those who are constantly toxic, but for those of us who slip-up? I don't see the point or efficiency in doing so.

What you're doing is totally fine. Neutral or positive play is really all we're asking for.

"Me keeping quiet and playing the game as normal, is me being sportsmanlike." Just keep doing what you're doing, you don't need to be some paragon of good behavior to get loot. Just play games and don't create bad experiences for other people.

Riot's ban system has always had a revolving door policy.

If you've been banned before, you will be more likely to show up for review over even the most minor infractions.

It's actually the opposite of that. The majority of players that receive a penalty, never receive another. That goes for every tier of punishment (most with a 10 game chat restriction never get a 25, most with a 25 game never get a 14-day, most with a 14-day never get a perma). That is why we perma-ban players if they continue their behavior after the 14-day ban.

Although that can be the perception by people who are perma banned, because they don't understand that their behavior is unacceptable.

> Although that can be the perception by people who are perma banned, because they don't understand that their behavior is unacceptable.

In some cases _(at least in my own case, but I can't be the only one)_, it's not that they don't understand that it's unacceptable, but that they're trying to deal with their behavior in the wrong manner.

I thought that if I could just try to focus and keep my mind on the game, that I could tune out the negativity and could avoid going off. As it turns out, though, I was taking the wrong approach. Sweeping the problem under the rug isn't the same as actually solving it, and it took the most serious of punishments before I was actually FORCED to stop and think about where the problem actually was _(in my case, the problem was in my lack of self-confidence and trying to handle everything on my own)_.

I'm not disagreeing with you, though. I just wanted to share my own perspective on the matter.

That's actually a very good perspective to share. That's the main reason why we added reform cards. We wanted people to have the ability to actually see why they were penalized, hoping they would be able to then realize what they need to do. I'm going to link to this for my own reference.

> [{quoted}](name=Riot Tantram,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=unobngtr,comment-id=0022000000000000,timestamp=2016-04-04T23:20:44.056+0000)
>
> That's actually a very good perspective to share. That's the main reason why we added reform cards. We wanted people to have the ability to actually see why they were penalized, hoping they would be able to then realize what they need to do. I'm going to link to this for my own reference.

"What they need to do" is different from person to person, though, and it isn't something an automated system can tell them. Obviously I wouldn't expect it to, since it's only a program and can't discern an individual's psychology.

For some people, just steeling their resolve and avoiding saying negative things works. These are likely the people who don't progress past the chat restriction tiers. _(There's also muting/not using chat, but this IS a social/teamwork game at its core, so that feels like more of a band-aid fix. Paranoia over the idea of being reported for the slightest of things likely doesn't help, but that's more to do with peoples' perceptions of the Instant Feedback system.)_

For the people this doesn't work for, though, the actual solution is much less clear. It's easy to still think that "just don't be negative in chat" is the answer, since it's the easiest and most obvious way out, and it's what a reform card seems to indicate on the surface. Like I said, that's the trap I got caught in. 

Thanks for reading and responding to my thoughts, by the way. I don't want to take up too much of your time, so I'll leave it at this. Any further and this'd turn into a discussion of human psychology, which isn't a field I'm certified in.
